posts.cooked: Hi everyone! Reefscape marks my first season in FRC, the FIRST Robotics Competition. Turrets have consistently stood out to me in many robots, particularly in shooting mechanics, offering dynamic targeting and real-time shooting advantages. Yet, I'm uncertain about our team's capability to build one effectively. What are your thoughts? Has any of our team members or others successfully developed a functional turret? How long did it take your team to create one? Additionally, considering the trade-offs such as complexity, weight, and tuning, is a turret still advisable for ensuring consistency and reliability? With Crescendo approaching, will the value of turrets diminish due to changes in gameplay? Thanks for your insights!

posts.name: Tom

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5554 - Alumni. Former head of software, strategy and development

posts.name: Wilson
posts.cooked: A turret offers two primary advantages: enhanced defense by not requiring orientation during pinning and increased rotational efficiency compared to driving or slowing down to face a target. However, due to swerve's prevalence, turrets lose their speed edge. Turrets only gain cycle speed benefits if numerous game pieces surround the target and can be efficiently indexed. Consequently, turrets proved most effective for cleanup teams with well-designed intakes capable of handling quick indexing. Ultimately, while turrets are valuable, they will only boost cycle speed under specific conditions involving rapid piece intake and indexing.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Turrets are very important, although they aren’t essential for achieving high rankings like 27 and 1678 in 2022. While IMO turrets excel during defensive slags, particularly when your team faces intense defensive pressure due to historical dominance or high placements, these advantages diminish significantly. In fact, swerve and vision have largely taken the power out of turrets, making them less crucial in modern gameplay.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: The Shooter on a Turret is a term that has been evolving in significance. In recent years, it's become clear that while once it was considered extremely important, its current value has diminished. Similarly, anything else located on a Turret also holds less importance compared to its historical status.

posts.name: Ainesh Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: The assistant addressed the user's request to clean up the provided text by focusing on removing HTML tags and unnecessary elements while ensuring the output remains coherent and preserves the original meaning. In their latest response, they demonstrated an understanding of the requirement to avoid introducing new explanations or formatting beyond the specified constraints.

posts.name: Brandon King
posts.cooked: It can be helpful to have a turret when your strategy requires performing one action with your shooter/end effector while performing another action with a mechanism that requires the robot to face in a certain direction, such as an intake picking up a game piece. Alternatively, it allows you to align with a target while under defense. However, implementing turrets from a controls standpoint can be quite challenging.

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: If you have the time and money to build one in the off-season, I'd say go ahead and try it out and learn from it. Some mechanical and software parts of a turret, which are useful on other areas of a robot, include tracking and alignment to the scoring target, managing wires for a rotating mechanism, and ensuring accurate position readings.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Wire management and large-bore bearings are the main challenges when working with turret systems. Slip rings with significant gaps are both costly and unreliable, requiring careful consideration due to their high power consumption. Proper planning during wire routing prevents potential failures. We successfully integrated these components into a competition robot, overcoming the complexities of cable management and ultimately securing the system through strategic bolt-on installation.

You’re missing a third way. It looks cool and vanity is the only thing that matters. But yeah, I agree that swerve and a good driver can provide a lot of the same benefits as a turret with a lot less development time and resources.

Rarely. To build a turret effectively requires significant effort and resources, and only when constructed exceptionally well does it begin to offer benefits. Even then, underperforming turrets can lead to negative consequences such as stiffness loss, increased weight, and packaging drawbacks, all of which can impede performance. Additionally, these challenges often come with time costs and software complications. For most teams, the mere presence of a turret introduces unintended hindrances.

The utility of turrets is rare and specific. They prove valuable primarily when independent positioning of mechanisms is desired without relying on the drivetrain—a situation not commonly encountered. For instance, in 2024, turrets were beneficial for 2910 due to the emphasis on defense through improved feeding strategies. However, their impact was minimal during cleanup operations, where 1323 proved more effective than utilizing a turret.

In 2022, turrets still offered limited advantages, despite being considered among the best-performing robots that year. Defense was adequately addressed through strategic matching and aggressive driving, with minor weight savings contributing positively. Additionally, sacrificing a turret allowed for a shooter with enhanced stiffness, which was advantageous in certain scenarios.

Notably, in 2020, team 1690 achieved success by building an extremely stiff shooter without a turret, demonstrating the potential benefits of eliminating turrets in specific contexts. Conversely, in 2017, turrets were less effective because prioritizing accuracy, throughput, and hopper space became more critical, areas where turrets often fell short. This pattern held true across multiple years—2019, 2016, 2013, and beyond—where turrets provided little to no additional benefit compared to alternative approaches.

It depends on several factors, such as the number of gamepieces you can hold, your shooting speed, and whether you can pick up and shoot without repositioning. In 2024, turrets weren’t adopted much because the source was on the opposite side of the field, allowing you to shoot as you drove back. Additionally, holding only one note meant you had to shoot quickly before moving on to another, so turret tracking wasn’t very useful.

In contrast, turrets were commonly used in 2022 due to shorter distances between pickup and scoring. Teams could hold two notes and shoot into the goal while moving to get the next piece. Without turrets, you’d need to reposition after each shot, increasing vulnerability to defense.

posts.name: Julian Fernandez
posts.cooked: One of the main advantages is the ability to pick up pieces as you score, allowing you to disconnect your drivetrain from your scoring action. In my opinion, using swerve means you don't need a turret to perform the same action; instead, good code ensures you stay aligned as you move. Turrets prove extremely challenging to build reliably, even for the most skilled teams. Consequently, drivers depend heavily on their turrets functioning properly during matches. However, those with a dependable turret and swerve in 2022 had a significant advantage, enabling them to focus on other aspects of the game.

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked: I love building turrets. In fact, I built four of them every year. Most teams do not benefit from building a turret. The added design, build, and program time is less than driver time, especially with SWRVE.
Appreciate you sharing this — sounds like way more pain than it’s worth. We’ll think twice.
Yeah, I hadn’t thought about it that way. How many game pieces you can carry at the same time is the key factor.
vanity is the reason why I even considered it in the first place

posts.name: Asher Broadhead
posts.cooked: We used turreted cameras this year, and they can significantly enhance shooting accuracy. Other than that, they perform exceptionally well when shooting, particularly when the time between the pickup and release of the gamepiece is very short.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Skipper, Driver, Bit of Everything, FRC 4774

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Turrets allow you to separate your intake and shooting directions effectively. Their value varies depending on the game, with additional benefits like swerving further enhancing drive direction decoupling.

We utilized turrets successfully from 2020/2021 through 2022, though they have become quite rare since then.

Given the constraints of not being able to construct custom slip rings and limited availability of appropriate COTS (Commercial, off-the-shelf) solutions, managing wiring connections remains a significant challenge.

Considering rotating the shooter hood could be a viable alternative to avoid wiring complications altogether.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: For Crescendo, 2910 had swerve AND a turret! It was super cool looking

data.title: When is it appropriate to build a turret?
data.fancy_title: When is it appropriate to build a turret?
